fields.description:
When an BFEBS image is registered with block device mapping options, the metadata service does not show correct block device mapping information:

*example of euca-register command*

euca-register .... -b /dev/sda1=snap-xxxxx,/dev/sdb=ephemeral0 ...

*metadata service block-device mapping output using [facter|https://github.com/puppetlabs/facter/blob/master/lib/facter/ec2.rb]*

{code}
root@ip-xxx-xxx-xxx-187:/usr/lib/ruby/vendor_ruby/facter# facter |grep ec2
ec2_ami_id => emi-D5863F3D
ec2_ami_launch_index => 0
ec2_block_device_mapping_emi => sda1
ec2_block_device_mapping_ephemeral => sda2
ec2_block_device_mapping_ephemeral0 => sda2
ec2_block_device_mapping_root => /dev/sda1
ec2_block_device_mapping_swap => sda3
ec2_hostname => 10.0.1.107
ec2_instance_id => i-864744DD
ec2_instance_type => m1.small
ec2_kernel_id => eki-13B43871
......
{code}

This affects cloud configuration management and bootstrapping scripts.
fields.summary: Metadata service doesn't show correct block device mapping for BFEBS instance when block device mapping is set with euca-register

comments.body: check for what is possible within the 3.2 timeframe
Determined that fix is too intrusive for 3.2
tim, can you confirm if this issue is too intrusive for 3.2.x in general or just not this first release of 3.2?
Just for 3.2, we can look at this for other versions of 3.2.  Please prioritize for sustaining!
Chuck to assess this one and provide input.

Admittedly, we have multiple problems to sort out with block-device mappings. And we'll try. But probably not everything can be done in the upcoming sustaining release. Do you guys ([~hspencer] or [~lwade]) know what specific problem is the blocker here? Is it that 'ec2_block_device_mapping_ephemeral' and 'ec2_block_device_mapping_ephemeral0' do not return 'sdb' as they should?
Hey [~dmitrii], correct, in this case yes its the ephemeral specified with registration not matching what is actually seen.
Removing from 3.2.1.  This needs additional investigation and possibly more significant design changes.

Hey [~dmitrii], 

I put some of this information in EUCA-4081, but AWS has defined what they support for instance store device names:

* http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html#InstanceStoreDeviceNames

They mention here the following:

"Instances that use Amazon EBS for the root device do not, by default, have instance store available at boot time. Also, you can't attach instance store volumes after you've launched an instance. Therefore, if you want your Amazon EBS-backed instance to use instance store volumes, you must specify them using a block device mapping when you create your AMI or launch your instance."

Additionally, they provide a table of what device should be based upon vm.type.  Here is a snippet of it (based upon Linux instances):

* /dev/sda2	Formatted and mounted as /mnt or /media/ephemeral0 on m1.small and c1.medium instances.
* /dev/sdb	Formatted and mounted as /mnt or /media/ephemeral0 on m1.medium, m1.large, m1.xlarge, c1.xlarge, cc1.4xlarge, cc2.8xlarge, m2.xlarge, m2.2xlarge, m2.4xlarge, and hi1.4xlarge.
* /dev/sdc	Available on m1.large, m1.xlarge, cc2.8xlarge, cc1.4xlarge, c1.xlarge, and hi1.4xlarge.
* /dev/sdd	Available on m1.xlarge, c1.xlarge, and cc2.8xlarge.
* /dev/sde	Available on m1.xlarge and c1.xlarge.

In short, I am thinking for the vm.types we support, we make sure and support these instance device mappings.  AWS also documents instance stores available on instance types:

* http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html#StorageOnInstanceTypes

Maybe we could map the instance stores to the instance types, along with the device mapping to help us be more in-live with AWS?  Not sure how much redesign has to be done for this part of the code.

I think the above information gives some insight as to the AWS documentation here:

* http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/block-device-mapping-concepts.html

With all this being said, we definitely should make sure we document it (maybe in different tables like what AWS has done), so users can be aware of what instance types we support, and what instance store devices we offer for each instance type.  Thoughts?

Hey [~hspencer],

Thanks for the AWS references. It is true that we do not support the ephemeral devices of VM Types faithfully. To be precise, until recently, we did not even have all the VM Types that AWS currently supports. When [~swathi] and [~awithrow] and I discussed topics related to the block-device mapping work she is doing, we did touch upon VM Types and agreed that it was a topic for future design and specification, not something that was straightforward enough to just tack onto the current effort. (Potential complications include rethinking how disk space is managed on the back end for these additional block devices and then involving the UI team to allow easy configuration of these more elaborate VM Types.) To my knowledge this is not something that Euca users have complained about, which is why I think the topic has not been of high priority so far. If you know otherwise, though, be sure to let [~shashi] know, so we can spec it and put on the roadmap promptly. The work that [~swathi] has put in gets us closer to faithful support of VM Types in the future. 

Thanks,
Dmitrii

Implementation for EUCA-4786 fixes this bug to the extent that metadata service returns the block device mappings based on run instance and register image requests. This fix does NOT guarantee an exact match between the actual device mappings on the VM instance and those requested by the end user in run instance/register image requests (because of hypervisor limitations).

Added new eutester suite to test multiple block device mapping scenarios for ebs backed instances. The test executes a variety of maps set at registration time, run-time, and both reg+runtime. Each test run now includes a metadata check which iterates through the block device mapping and metadata service to compare. Please see attached eutester code and test log/output snippets. I think the one inconsistency is the reporting of ephemeral disk which is still being tracked in euca-6048. If the test is now passing so moving this ticket to resolved, but if it looks incomplete or incorrect please let me know. 
Thanks!
-Matt


{code}



###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
From block device mapping test:
###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
...
...
self.status('Check block device mapping meta data...')
meta_bdm = instance.block_device_mapping
  #Temp work around for existing bug where ephemeral is not reported...
  if not meta_bdm.has_key(bdm_ephemeral_dev):
    self.resulterr('Ephemeral disk not reported in instance block dev mapping: see euca-6048')
    meta_bdm[bdm_ephemeral_dev] = eph_dev
instance.check_instance_meta_data_for_block_device_mapping(root_dev=image.root_device_name, bdm=meta_bdm)
...
...

###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
From euinstance class:
###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
def check_instance_meta_data_for_block_device_mapping(self, root_dev=None, bdm=None):
        '''
        Checks current instances meta data against a provided block device map & root_dev, or
        against the current values of the instance; self.block_device_mapping & self.root_device_name
        '''
        self.tester.print_block_device_map(self.block_device_mapping)
        meta_dev_names = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping')
        meta_devices = {}
        root_dev = root_dev or self.root_device_name
        orig_bdm = bdm or self.block_device_mapping
        bdm = copy.copy(orig_bdm)
        if root_dev in bdm:
            bdm.pop(root_dev)

        meta_ami = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/ami')
        if not root_dev in meta_ami:
            raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/ami":' + str(meta_ami) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
        meta_dev_names.remove('ami')
        meta_emi = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/emi')
        if not root_dev in meta_emi :
            raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/emi":' + str(meta_emi) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
        meta_dev_names.remove('emi')
        meta_root = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/root')
        if not root_dev in meta_root:
            raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/root":' + str(meta_root) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
        meta_dev_names.remove('root')
        if self.root_device_type == 'ebs':
            meta_ebs1 = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/ebs1')
            if not root_dev in meta_ebs1:
                raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/ebs1":' + str(meta_ebs1) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
            meta_dev_names.remove('ebs1')

        for device in meta_dev_names:
            meta_devices[device] =  self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/' + str(device))[0]

        for device in bdm:
            found = False
            device_map = bdm[device]
            if device_map.no_device:
                continue
            else:
                if device_map.ephemeral_name:
                    dev_name_prefix = 'ephemeral'
                else:
                    dev_name_prefix = 'ebs'
                for meta_dev in meta_devices:
                    if str(meta_dev).startswith(dev_name_prefix):
                        if meta_devices.get(meta_dev) == device:
                            self.debug('Found meta data match for block device:' + str(device) + " at: " + str(meta_dev))
                            meta_devices.pop(meta_dev)
                            found = True
                            break
                if not found:
                    raise Exception('No meta data found for block dev map device:' + str(device))
        if meta_devices:
            err_buf = 'Unknown meta data found for the following not in:' + str(self.id) + "'s block_device_mapping:"
            for meta_dev in meta_devices:
                err_buf += "'" + str(meta_dev) + ":" + str(meta_devices.get(meta_dev)) + "', "
            raise Exception(err_buf)



###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
Test output:

###############################################################################################
